name: Verwey, Albert aan Gosse, Edmund William | 1885-10-01

Transcription.text:
¶Edm. W. Gosse Esqre

Sir,

Herewith I have the honor to present you with a copy of De 'Nieuwe Gids'.
    After perusal of the accompanying Prospectus you will be aware that the N.G. is the periodical of those students of litterature who cannot see their way in the Existing reviews.
    They wish to realize kind of a revolution in the art [&?] litterature of their country - not only to secure success for their own productions, but also to lead the tastes of their (civilized) countrymen to the best of English poets, who have been their models for several years.
    This cannot be done without the help of as many friends as we will contrive to find in this country and abroad. And I hope you will Excuse the liberty with which I ask your assistance. ¶    Because they could not carry out this purpose without as much assistance as they could contrive to find, they sought and were happy enough to find in their own country men of art, of science, and of politics who were ready to lend their aid.
    The first number of the N.G. is the result of their combined efforts.
    And now, I hope you will Excuse the liberty with which I draw your attention to a copy of this new periodical.
   [X] are known in this country as one who speaks the Dutch language and translated Dutch poetry. If any Englishman is likely to feel interested in the litterary movement, which it is originated from, it certainly must be you
